Detailed Description

The media object.

Stores all information about the media (hash-value, tags, modification date, length, rating, etc.) Gets serialized into XML, so we can store it in our database

Definition at line 405 of file Media.cs.

Property Documentation

Uri Crossfade::Media::uri [get, set]

We describe the location of each media object with an URI, even if it's stored on the local hard-disk.

This generalized handling makes it easy to implement methods which a) work always, regardless whether it's a local file or a http-stream and b) can easily differentiate between different types of access (local file, http-stream, crossfade-http-stream with port 21000, etc.)

Thanks to the mighty great .NET, we can't serialize the Uri object into XML so we need a funny hack (see below)

Definition at line 418 of file Media.cs.

Referenced by commitToTag(), Crossfade::FileInfo::getInfo(), Crossfade::P2PDB::query(), and Crossfade::MediaDB::rebuild().

string Crossfade::Media::_uriSerializable [get, set]

Thank you .NET - nobody would have known in advance, that someone actually wants to serialize an Uri object .

.. into a STRING !!! So we create a fake property, which maps the Uri into a string, which can then be serialized by .NET to XML.

Definition at line 438 of file Media.cs.

DateTime Crossfade::Media::MTime [get, set]

The date of last modification of the media file.

Only valid if the uri scheme is file:/
